LIFE113
Notes
Currently, as part of LIFE109 module, QS is “dribbled” out over two semesters. This raises the following issues:
Students forget content covered in lectures/tutorials prior to workshops/assessment.
Content delivered in a discontinuous manner in order to satisfy requirements of second semester modules (e.g. necessary delivery of stats prior to 107 module breaks flow of non-stats content).

A single semester delivery would mean that students engage more frequently with the module and are able to build on knowledge as they progress with less opportunity to forget what they have learned. Also, a more logical ordering of content could be implemented as there would no need to satisfy content delivered in other modules.


The majority of the content for this module will remain identical to that currently delivered as part of LIFE109 QS. Key differences include a reduction in stats related content and the addition of content related specifically to tools for quantitative skills (i.e. Excel and R). All content will be streamlined accordingly to fit into a single semester and care taken to maintain realistic module aims without overwhelming students.

The new module will supersede the current Quantitative Skills half of the LIFE109 module.

The new Graduate Skills modules (LIFE130) and this new module (LIFE113) will be completely independent of each other. No content or data will be shared between the modules. That said, skills developed in 113 will inevitably be required for assessments that involve data analysis or calculations (e.g. Scientific Report) in 130.

All summative tests will be preceeded by a relevant formative test. Students will need to attempt the formative tests before being permitted to attempt the summative ones. This will increase student engagement with quantitative based problems and ensure that they practice their skills prior to summative testing.

There will be no pass mark associated with any formative test. The only requirement is that they are attempted. Students will be free to attempt the formative tests as many times as they like prior to summative tests in order to ‘learn by doing’ and to build their confidence.

The module will be a component of ALL Life Science Programmes. For more info visit: https://www.liverpool.a...sciences/undergraduate/

Overview

Overview
This module delivers a syllabus of quantitative skills required for Life Science students throughout their programmes. The module is designed to fit a broad spectrum of ability and assumes little prior knowledge of maths, statistics and digital competency.

Focus is placed on the use of digital tools (spreadsheets, relevant statistical packages) to manipulate, analyse and visualise authentic biological datasets from fields relevant to Life Science programmes. Knowledge and application of such tools will enhance graduate employability.
Features
Embedded digital skills training.

Key emphasis will be placed on the use of digital tools (spreadsheets, coding languages) to help solve numerical problems in a wide range of research based biological contexts.

The development of digital skills is highly aligned with the Curriculum 2021 Digital Fluency graduate attribute. Furthermore, the delivery of teaching in these skills will be consistent with the Hallmarks for Active Learning and Research-connected teaching.

Innovative approaches to the delivery of online testing, involving the dynamic generation of numerical questions and feedback, will ensure that the third "Authentic Assessment" hallmark of Curriculum 2021 is addressed.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Develop in students the essential quantitative and digital skills that they will require to be competent Life Scientists.

2. Develop critical thinking and problem solving skills.

3. Introduce students to the use of basic digital tools for handling data and visualising data.

4. Introduce students to computer programming (fundamental component of digital technology) that will enable them to perform robust statistical analysis of biological datasets.
Marketing Module Synopsis
For any student studying the Biological Sciences a firm grasp of quantitiative skills is an absolute necessity. This module will provide you with the knowledge and skills you need to manipulate numbers and analysis/visualise data using digital tools. The module emphasises a "learn by doing" approach to the development of quantitative skills and is heavily workshop based.
Outline Syllabus
Section A: Fundamentals

A0. Maths Refresher and QS Introduction
A1. Introduction to Excel
A2. Manipulating numbers
A3. Units and Conversion
A4. Molarities and Concentrations
A5. Linear Equations
A6. Non-linear equations and logarithms
A7. Probability

Section B: Statistics

B1. Introduction to R
B2. Descriptive Statistics
B3. Hypothesis building and testing
B4. Inferential Statistics
Teaching and Learning Methods
1. Online Streamed Lectures: This refers to timetabled lectures which explain core mathematical concepts. This will be delivered online

2. Online Workshops: Core concepts from lectures will be reinforced by active, problem based learning. Workshops will be supported using asynchronous video content that will be more accessible to students in an online environment.

3. Tutorials: Online interactive sessions that encourage students to engage with quantitative skills resources and provide feedback on assessment.

4. Peer Assisted Learning (PAL) sessions: Student led sessions that support problem based learning approach.

5. Webinars: These sessions will be streamed "live" from teachers desktop to demonstrate use of digital tools for statistics and coding.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
All assessment for this module (formative and summative) will be delivered in the form of online MCQ tests.

Formative and summative, open book, online tests will be of the same format and drawn from dynamic question pools. For each student, every test will be unique. Formative online tests will be used to encourage students to practice questions in each of the sections, i.e. A1, A2 ... etc. Students will need to attempt formative tests before being permitted to attempt the end of section summative tests.

Deliveries

Outcomes

 L4-1 Use digital tools for data processing and visualisation.
 L4-2 Understand how to construct and test experimental hypotheses.
 L4-4 Use a programming language for analysis and visualisation of large data sets and the application of statistics.

Content delivered in a discontinuous manner in order to satisfy requirements of second semester modules (e.g. necessary delivery of stats prior to 107 module breaks flow of non-stats content).

A single semester delivery would mean that students engage more frequently with the module and are able to build on knowledge as they progress with less opportunity to forget what they have learned. Also, a more logical ordering of content could be implemented as there would no need to satisfy content delivered in other modules.


The majority of the content for this module will remain identical to that currently delivered as part of LIFE109 QS. Key differences include a reduction in stats related content and the addition of content related specifically to tools for quantitative skills (i.e. Excel and R). All content will be streamlined accordingly to fit into a single semester and care taken to maintain realistic module aims without overwhelming students.

The new module will supersede the current Quantitative Skills half of the LIFE109 module.

The new Graduate Skills modules (LIFE130) and this new module (LIFE113) will be completely independent of each other. No content or data will be shared between the modules. That said, skills developed in 113 will inevitably be required for assessments that involve data analysis or calculations (e.g. Scientific Report) in 130.

All summative tests will be preceeded by a relevant formative test. Students will need to attempt the formative tests before being permitted to attempt the summative ones. This will increase student engagement with quantitative based problems and ensure that they practice their skills prior to summative testing.

There will be no pass mark associated with any formative test. The only requirement is that they are attempted. Students will be free to attempt the formative tests as many times as they like prior to summative tests in order to ‘learn by doing’ and to build their confidence.

The module will be a component of ALL Life Science Programmes. For more info visit: https://www.liverpool.a...sciences/undergraduate/

Overview

Overview
This module delivers a syllabus of quantitative skills required for Life Science students throughout their programmes. The module is designed to fit a broad spectrum of ability and assumes little prior knowledge of maths, statistics and digital competency.

Focus is placed on the use of digital tools (spreadsheets, relevant statistical packages) to manipulate, analyse and visualise authentic biological datasets from fields relevant to Life Science programmes. Knowledge and application of such tools will enhance graduate employability.
Features
Embedded digital skills training.

Key emphasis will be placed on the use of digital tools (spreadsheets, coding languages) to help solve numerical problems in a wide range of research based biological contexts.

The development of digital skills is highly aligned with the Curriculum 2021 Digital Fluency graduate attribute. Furthermore, the delivery of teaching in these skills will be consistent with the Hallmarks for Active Learning and Research-connected teaching.

Innovative approaches to the delivery of online testing, involving the dynamic generation of numerical questions and feedback, will ensure that the third "Authentic Assessment" hallmark of Curriculum 2021 is addressed.
Educational Aims
This module aims to:

1. Develop in students the essential quantitative and digital skills that they will require to be competent Life Scientists.

2. Develop critical thinking and problem solving skills.

3. Introduce students to the use of basic digital tools for handling data and visualising data.

4. Introduce students to computer programming (fundamental component of digital technology) that will enable them to perform robust statistical analysis of biological datasets.
Marketing Module Synopsis
For any student studying the Biological Sciences a firm grasp of quantitiative skills is an absolute necessity. This module will provide you with the knowledge and skills you need to manipulate numbers and analysis/visualise data using digital tools. The module emphasises a "learn by doing" approach to the development of quantitative skills and is heavily workshop based.
Outline Syllabus
Section A: Fundamentals

A0. Maths Refresher and QS Introduction
A1. Introduction to Excel
A2. Manipulating numbers
A3. Units and Conversion
A4. Molarities and Concentrations
A5. Linear Equations
A6. Non-linear equations and logarithms
A7. Probability

Section B: Statistics

B1. Introduction to R
B2. Descriptive Statistics
B3. Hypothesis building and testing
B4. Inferential Statistics
Teaching and Learning Methods
1. Online Streamed Lectures: This refers to timetabled lectures which explain core mathematical concepts. This will be delivered online

2. Online Workshops: Core concepts from lectures will be reinforced by active, problem based learning. Workshops will be supported using asynchronous video content that will be more accessible to students in an online environment.

3. Tutorials: Online interactive sessions that encourage students to engage with quantitative skills resources and provide feedback on assessment.

4. Peer Assisted Learning (PAL) sessions: Student led sessions that support problem based learning approach.

5. Webinars: These sessions will be streamed "live" from teachers desktop to demonstrate use of digital tools for statistics and coding.

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
All assessment for this module (formative and summative) will be delivered in the form of online MCQ tests.

Formative and summative, open book, online tests will be of the same format and drawn from dynamic question pools. For each student, every test will be unique. Formative online tests will be used to encourage students to practice questions in each of the sections, i.e. A1, A2 ... etc. Students will need to attempt formative tests before being permitted to attempt the end of section summative tests.

 L4-1 Use digital tools for data processing and visualisation.
 L4-2 Understand how to construct and test experimental hypotheses.
 L4-4 Use a programming language for analysis and visualisation of large data sets and the application of statistics.
